From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Self-adaptive Mutation Rates, Novelty Search and CMA-ES
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=q187MPNSwotuARIQScOVM-if7ceu704YN-bHtvsje3vMzLi1RbWi
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hi Ken,

Please see below.


> Hi Jeff, on the issue itself of whether SAMR=
s are actually useful in NS, I=92d agree that more investigation is warrant=
ed, but I also think it=92s important to be precise about what we are expec=
ting it to help with.  For example, it may very well help one sense of evol=
vability (e.g. ability to generate immediate behavioral variation) but not =
another (e.g. ability to generate solutions to a variety of different probl=
ems).  In any case, the jury is out seems like a reasonable position at the=
 moment.
>  
> Outside just the topic of SAMRs (and also related to Oliver'=
s recent response in this thread), the idea of a =93novelty plateau=94 is i=
nteresting but I think it similarly warrants care and precision in how it=
=92s articulated.  It=92s tempting to import terminology from our objective=
 upbringing into the non-objective world, but it can lead to misleading or =
even inaccurate intuitions.  For example, you said, =93Novelty plateaus exi=
st when, during novelty search, mutating the current population does not im=
mediately produce new behaviors.=94  This statement seems to carry with it =
some implicit intuitions from the objective world that are probably mislead=
ing. 
>  
> For example, we are used to thinking of the =93current populati=
on=94 being stuck on a fitness =93plateau,=94 but that=92s only because we =
are used to the idea of the population converging to higher fitness.  Becau=
se of that, we are used to thinking of the whole population being subject t=
o a kind of correlating force that pushes it collectively into a common sit=
uation.  Yet talking about the whole population at once being stuck on a no=
velty plateau evokes an analogy with that situation that is almost assuredl=
y incorrect, because novelty search is a divergent search so there is no re=
ason that the =93current population=94 would be expected to be at all corre=
lated in their current predicament.  That is, some individuals may be =93st=
uck=94 to varying degrees (probably not 100% stuck), but some may not.  And=
 certainly even among those sort of stuck, they are not stuck for similar r=
easons, which is quite different than what we mean by a =93plateau=94 in a =
population with respect to fitness.
> 
When I mentioned that we think popul=
ations can be on a novelty plateau, all I meant is that the entire populati=
on is in a situation in which mutations are not producing new behaviors. Yo=
u are right to point out that they are not necessarily on the same plateau;=
 all we mean is that all of the organisms are on plateaus simultaneously.

=
>  
> Relating to the 100% point, it's important to keep in mind that the g=
radient for novelty is not actually exhausted in the case that it cannot fi=
nd immediately something certifiably =93new=94 for the archive.  Rather, al=
l it needs is that some behaviors are more novel than others with respect t=
o the current archive.  Even minute differences in that respect provide som=
e gradient.  I=92m having trouble even imagining how such a gradient could =
entirely disappear for the whole population.  
>  
> 
Yes, that is the poin=
t I was trying to make when I said in the previous e-mail "let me now argue=
 with myself.=94 It's an interesting idea, and it may just be the reason wh=
y the pathology of self adaptive mutation rates does not show up in Novelty=
 Search. I look forward to seeing whether or not additional research bears =
that hypothesis out. 

I should point out that I don't think this point pre=
cludes another problem with novelty plateaus that the paper we are about to=
 announce addresses.  More on that soon.

> Of course, there is the excepti=
onal (and unlikely) case where all possible mutations to an individual at t=
he current mutation rate somehow ruin it completely.   But even in that cas=
e (going back to the SAMR), I=92m not sure why =93there is no incentive to =
have a high mutation rate.=94  Wouldn=92t it rather be the case that a high=
 mutation is one way you could potentially escape to a new behavior (which =
would then be rewarded)?  There=92s always somewhere you can go in one step=
 as long as the search space isn=92t completely devoid of anything interest=
ing.
> 
I can imagine a situation, which I'm guessing is not that uncommon,=
 in which a complex behavior mostly breaks if mutated at a high mutation ra=
te. In that case most of the mutants fall on the presumably huge pile of br=
oken behaviors, and thus get very low novelty scores. I can further imagine=
 that a very low mutation rate applied to the same behavior produces the ex=
act same behavior or something very similar. Those behaviors would be more =
novel then broken behaviors. Thus there'll be a pressure to lower mutation =
rates. Finally, I can imagine that if a fixed mutation rate agenda was appl=
ied to the original behavior, it may ultimately produce a very complex, nov=
el behavior. Thus the pressure to lower mutation rates would prevent the di=
scovery of that new behavior. I recognize that is a very hand-wavy explanat=
ion, but to me it suggests that the typical pathologies of self adaptive mu=
tation rates may still exist even with novelty search. I really think we ne=
ed more investigation into this issue and I hope that many people in our co=
mmunity decide to look into it.

>  
> Anyway, my main concern is not with =
defending SAMR for NS, I think it=92s good to keep the jury out on that.   =
I=92m more worried in general about projecting intuitions about the objecti=
ve world into novelty search and thereby causing us to think about novelty =
like we would an objective, when really these are very different worlds wit=
h different properties and different kinds of challenges.
> 
I agree. I app=
reciate you pointing out the differences, as they are always fun and comple=
x to think about!

>  
> Best,
>  
> ken
> 
> 
> 

--Apple-Mail=_980EC241-1810-4E8B-9F6B-7EF72FC25AE7
